#Text=Ugochukwu-Smooth Nzewi
#Text=Ugochukwu-Smooth C. Nzewi is a Nigerian artist , art historian , and curator , currently Curator of African art at Cleveland Museum of Art .
#Text=He was raised in Enugu and studied under sculptor El Anatsui at the University of Nigeria , Nsukka , before traveling as an artist and curator .
#Text=In the United States , he completed his doctorate at Emory University in 2013 and became the curator of African art at Dartmouth College 's Hood Museum of Art .
#Text=In 2017 , he moved to the Cleveland Museum of Art .

#Text=Nzewi has curated the Nigerian Afrika Heritage Biennial three times , the Dak'Art biennial in 2014 , and independent exhibitions at Atlanta 's High Museum of Art and New York 's Richard Taittinger Gallery .
#Text=Nzewi also exhibited internationally as an artist and artist-in-resident .
#Text=Early life and career
#Text=Nzewi was born in Nigeria [ 1 ] and raised in Enugu . [ 2 ]
#Text=He studied sculpture under El Anatsui at the University of Nigeria , Nsukka , and received a bachelor 's degree in fine and applied art in 2001 . [ 1 ] [ 3 ]

#Text=After graduating , Nzewi traveled internationally for six years as an independent artist and curator , [ 3 ] and was involved in the curation of three iterations of the Afrika Heritage Biennial . [ 4 ]

#Text=In 2006 , Nzewi moved to Cape Town , South Africa , where he worked on a yearlong postgraduate program in Museum and Heritage Studies at the University of Western Cape while serving as an artist-in-residence at the Greatmore Studio in Woodstock , Cape Town . [ 3 ]
#Text=The next year , 2007 , Nzewi moved to Atlanta , Georgia , and began a doctorate degree in art history at Emory University . [ 3 ]
#Text=During his doctoral years , he curated at Atlanta 's High Museum ( 2009 ) and received Robert Sterling Clark and Smithsonian fellowships . [ 4 ]
#Text=He wrote his dissertation on the Dak'Art biennial 's influence on contemporary African art , [ 1 ] and graduated in May 2013 . [ 3 ]
#Text=The following August , Nzewi became the Dartmouth College Hood Museum of Art 's first curator of African art , [ 5 ] [ 6 ] where he mounted shows on Eric Van Hove and Ekpe textiles .
#Text=After four years , Nzewi left Dartmouth to became the Cleveland Museum of Art 's curator of African art . [ 7 ]
#Text=Among his considerations as a curator , Nzewi cites the importance of art history and his curiosity in how artworks reveal collective social imagination through expression and interpretation .
#Text=He has expressed interest in learning from the creative process as artists make intellectual decisions about their work on reflection of how it will be received by others and the market . [ 3 ]
#Text=He has published essays in multiple academic art journals , contributed to Grove Art Online , and co-edited a volume on independent African art initiatives . [ 4 ]
#Text=Nzewi served among the three curators of the 2014 Dak'Art biennial , which focused on themes of globalization ( expressed through African ideas of communalism ) and anonymity . [ 3 ]
#Text=Dak'Art had served as important link between the African and international art world , and Nzewi helped to situate the show 's own role in developing " pan-African internationalism " . [ 4 ]
#Text=In mid-2015 , Nzewi curated a monthlong survey of African art at the Richard Taittinger Gallery in New York .
#Text=The show was named after the 1967 comedy-drama film Guess Who 's Coming to Dinner [ 2 ] [ 8 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=In late 2016 , Nzewi served as a guest curator at the Shanghai Biennale . [ 10 ]
#Text=As an artist , Nzewi has participated in shows and residencies in Africa , Europe , and the United States . [ 5 ]
#Text=He has collaborated with Emeka Ogboh , whom he met in college .

#Text=Under the moniker One-Room Shack , the pair prepared an installation for the Watermans Arts Centre in 2012 in which visitors walk through interconnected letters that spell " UNITY " , a reflection on the Olympic spirit . [ 11 ]
